title: Saturday Live Music at Spicy Vines feat. Quintessence
description:
Where unforgettable wines, live music, and good vibes come together. 

Join us every Saturday from 3‚Äì6 PM at Spicy Vines for a tasting room experience like no other ‚Äî where top local musicians from across the Bay Area meet our award-winning small-lot wines. From Rock & Roll and Blues to Jazz, Bluegrass, and Americana, each weekend brings new sounds and new reasons to raise a glass.¬†

Quintessence Music Duo Quintessence is a married musical duo whose shared passion for performing and songwriting creates a warm, reflective soundscape that celebrates both the ordinary and the extraordinary.¬†

Details

No cover. Walk-ins are welcome, but this event tends to fill up quickly, so we recommend making a reservation. We are dog and family friendly!

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Guitar Master Julio Reyes
description:
Julio Reyes: An Evening of Virtuoso Guitar at Occidental Center for the Arts Join us at Occidental Center for the Arts for an unforgettable night with acclaimed guitarist Julio Reyes, whose expressive playing and soulful command of the instrument have captivated audiences around the world. Blending Latin American traditions with contemporary flair, Reyes delivers a performance that is both intimate and electrifying-rich with original compositions, dazzling technique, and heartfelt storytelling through music. Julio will perform compositions by Bach, Barrios, Tarrega, Albeniz, Villa-lobos, Lauro, Jobim, and Heitmeyer. Experience the warmth, precision, and artistry of one of today's most compelling guitar voices up close in an evening that promises to inspire, uplift, and transport. Tickets are $30, $25 for OCA and RAC members. Doors open at 2:30 PM. Refreshments available. OCA is wheelchair accessible. Tickets for this event will be on sale so

title: Live Music - The Ukulele Ramblers - Open Uke Jam!
description:
Join us for a chill evening of live music and good vibes with The Ukulele Ramblers at our happy hour event!

Welcome to **Live Music - The Ukulele Ramblers - Open Uke Jam!** Join us for a fun-filled evening of live music and ukulele jamming at Barrel Proof Lounge. Bring your ukulele and strum along with The Ukulele Ramblers, a talented group of musicians who will be performing a mix of classic tunes and original songs. Whether you're a seasoned ukulele player or a beginner looking to learn, this event is perfect for all music lovers. So mark your calendars for Sundays and get ready to enjoy a night of great music and good vibes. See you there! Open Uke jam hosted by your friendly neighborhood Ukulele collective.

title: Classical Impressions: Music of the Fin de Si√®cle
description:
Recently formed in San Francisco, the Alora Quartet is dedicated to timeless beauty and connection through music. With a focus on transition, reflection, and momentum, the quartet brings each piece to life through its exploration of musical storytelling and resonance. Under the mentorship of Wonhee Bae and Yeeun Heo, first violinist and cellist of the Esm√© Quartet, the Alora Quartet brings a fresh perspective to the string quartet tradition, blending both tradition and innovation.

The name ‚ÄòAlora‚Äô is derived from the Italian word ‚Äòallora‚Äô, meaning ‚Äòthen‚Äô or ‚Äòso‚Äô, symbolizing the quartet‚Äôs evolving musical journey. The Alora Quartet has had the privilege of working with world-renowned violist and pedagogue Kim Kashkashian in a masterclass, an experience that has influenced their artistic development. The Alora Quartet was founded by violinists Cuna Kim and Qicong Ma, violist Phoebee Lee, and cellist Daniela Gonzales Siu.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

The 23rd Annual Art of Dessert

The Art of Dessert¬†is LBC‚Äôs biggest fundraising event of the year. Over the years, it has raised more than $8 million to help provide enrichment in the arts to over 1 million children, families, and educators. 

Much anticipated, spirited, and delicious,¬†The¬†Art of Dessert¬†features sumptuous family-style dining, exceptional Rodney Strong Wine Estates wines, engaging entertainment, a silent and live auction, and, of course, decadent desserts by the best bakers in the county! Bid on unique live auction items and enjoy lively entertainment and engaging speakers. Sonoma County‚Äôs best fundraiser is a night to remember, and your support will make a difference for over 50,000 students, teachers, and families in the coming year. 

WHY YOUR SUPPORT MATTERS 

Thanks to your support, Luther Burbank Center for the Arts is the North Bay‚Äôs premier arts nonprofit, a vibrant gathering place providing world-class performances, a wide variety of community events, and nationally-recognized education programs that annually serve over 50,000 students, teachers, and families.

**Get ready for a wild, laugh-out-loud adventure with *HEAD OVER HEELS*‚Äîthe electrifying musical comedy from the creative forces behind Hedwig and the Angry Inch, Avenue Q, and Spring Awakening! Nominated for *Outstanding New Broadway Musical* in 2019 and powered by the chart-topping hits of the legendary all-female rock band The Go-Go‚Äôs, this high-energy show features beloved anthems like ‚ÄúWe Got the Beat,‚Äù ‚ÄúOur Lips Are Sealed,‚Äù ‚ÄúVacation,‚Äù ‚ÄúHeaven is a Place on Earth,‚Äù and ‚ÄúMad About You.‚Äù**

**Join a spirited royal family on a whirlwind quest to save their kingdom from doom‚Äîonly to realize that the key to their future isn‚Äôt written in fate, but in their own hearts. Packed with irresistible music, over-the-top comedy, and a whole lot of love, *HEAD OVER HEELS* is a dazzling, feel-good spectacle that will have you dancing in your seat!**

title: Sebastopol Documentary Film Festival
description:
Revolutionizing the Film Festival Experience

The Sebastopol Documentary Film Festival is the San Francisco Bay Area's premier documentary film festival, offering four days of curated films, award presentations, cinephile panels and forums, upscale gatherings, VIP receptions, and casual meet-and-greets-all in the heart of Sonoma County.

From its roots as a local fest showing about 40 films in 2007, SDFF now receives more than 700 submissions from 62\+ countries per year. In 2025, 57 films were programmed and shown and the event was attended by filmmakers, as well as a robust audience of film lovers. In addition to its commitment to honoring diversity in all its forms by providing open calls for entry, SDFF is an Oscar¬Æ-qualifying film festival for short and mini form documentaries.

SDFF is proudly progressive in its curation of topics and forms. Now more than ever, festival organizers seek to amplify urgent messages, uplift stories from marginalized communities, and support earnest efforts to provoke political change, effect social justice, and encourage personal growth

For more information about how you can submit your film, volunteer to help with the fest, donate money, or promote our vital work, please visit https://www.sebastopolfilm.org/.

About SDFF \(Sebastopol Documentary Film Festival\):

Founded in 2007, the first ever Sebastopol Documentary Film Festival \(SDFF\) boldly curated 44 films that brought into focus a wealth of talented filmmakers from Sonoma County and the greater San Francisco Bay Area.

Sixteen years later, nearly 700 titles from 62 countries were openly submitted for SDFF 2023. Sixty-three films were programmed, the event was attended by 93 filmmakers and an impressive audience, through in-person and streaming delivery.

SDFF honors diversity in all forms. We continue to provide equal opportunity for filmmakers through open calls for entry; explore what it's like for any life to wake to its existence.

SDFF is an Oscar¬Æ qualifying Film Festival for documentaries in the short form. Sebastopol Documentary Film Festival is proudly progressive, often featuring spotlights on social justice, journalism, current issues. When the right films come through we've programmed different POV's of the same story. Given the proliferation of AI, documentaries might become our only touchstone for what was 'real' at a moment in time. What better platform than a non-fiction film festival to encourage fresh and critical thinking?

Date and Time: Thursday, 09 April 2026 at 09:00 - Sunday, 12 April 2026 at 17:00

title: Hook and Ladder Vineyards and Winery
description:
Callie Watts is a singer/songwriter from Northern California who was raised on classical music, The Beatles and The Beach Boys before discovering Joni Mitchell, Elton John, Stevie Wonder, Paul Simon, Billy Joel, Carole King, and all the great writers of the ‚Äô60s and 70‚Äôs who have influenced her sound and writing style. After graduating high school, Callie began playing and performing solo, as well as in local and bay area bands of different genres. She‚Äôs played blues with Eric Lindell and the Reds, funky soul with Phatty, and jazz/swing with Savoy Swingers along with many other various projects. Callie has taken turns throughout her career as a keyboardist, guitarist, writer, and lead/backing vocalist, and she‚Äôs currently a member of the dynamic Sonoma County funk rock band Burrows and Dilbeck, having joined in 2010 as part of the former band Frobeck. Over time, she‚Äôs had the honor of opening for acts such as Bootsy Collins, Elvin Bishop, Huey Lewis and The News, War, Ozomatli, Bill Champlin, Booker T, and the B52s. Callie continues to perform frequently as an acoustic solo artist, focusing on developing a core audience and a buzz for her original material. Come hang out and listen at venues such as Aroma Roasters, Rincon Valley Tap Room and Bottle Shop, and Hopmonk Tavern.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Richard Shindell
description:
Originally from New York, now dividing his time between Buenos Aires, Argentina and New York's Hudson Valley, Richard Shindell is a writer whose songs paint pictures, tell stories, juxtapose ideas and images, inhabit characters, vividly evoking entire worlds along the way and expanding our sense of just what it is a song may be. From his first record, Sparrow's Point \(1992\) to his current release, Careless \(September 2016\), Shindell has explored the possibilities offered by this most elastic and variable of cultural confections: the song.   

The path that led him to songwriting was both circuitous and direct. Taking up the guitar at the age of eight, he listened but imagined that composing a song was out of the question.

After college and a nine month stint in a Zen Buddhist community in Upstate New York, he headed to Europe with his guitar, finding something not approaching a livelihood performing in the Paris Metro, where he discovered  "I loved the acoustics in those tunnels, but only when they were empty." 

Upon running out of money he entered Union Theological Seminary, where the celestial acoustics of the chapel inspired his first "keeper" composition: On a Sea of Fleur de Lis. Ostensibly a paean to the Virgin Mary, the song marked his rupture from the church and the beginning of his creative life. Its underlying themes - immanence and transcendence, human love and divine love, the particular and the general - have continued to resonate through subsequent work, right up to the present. In many ways, his new album Careless, represents a further exploration of those ideas.   

Joining the songwriter scene in New York City led to a deal with Shanachie Records for Shindell‚Äôs first three albums:  Sparrows Point \(1992\), Blue Divide \(1994\), and Reunion Hill \(1997\). The latter, produced by multi-instrumentalist Larry Campbell, won the AFIM \(NAIRD\) award for "Best Contemporary Folk Album" in 1998. Its title track was covered by Joan Baez on her 1997 release, Gone From Danger. In 1998, Shindell joined forces with his friends Dar Williams and Lucy Kaplansky to make CryCryCry \(Razor and Tie\), a collection of covers. The group toured in support of this highly acclaimed album, leaving audiences spellbound by their gorgeous three-part harmonies. 

By then Shindell was beginning to stretch out as a harmony singer, guitarist and performer. In 1999, Shindell released a live band album, Courier \(Signature Sounds\) that remains a fan favorite. The year 2000 brought the release of a new collection of originals, Somewhere Near Paterson \(Signature Sounds\), produced by Campbell. That year also saw a major life-change: with his Argentine wife and their two small children, Shindell moved to Buenos Aires, Argentina. Taking a few years to get acclimated and learn the language, in 2004 he followed up with Vuelta \(Koch Records\), joining with Argentine band Puente Celeste. The decade's next release was a collection of covers, South of Delia \(2007\), Shindell's first foray into production. More than simply a cover record, the song-selections and performances of South of Delia were that of an expatriate looking back at the country and culture he moved away from. His next collection of original songs, Not Far Now, was released by Signature Sounds in 2009. For 13 Songs You May or May Not Have Heard Before, which The Telegraph \(UK\) called ‚Äúa stunningly good record‚Äù, Shindell revisited some of his earlier material, giving fresh interpretations to old favourites. 

In 2015 he joined forces again with Lucy Kaplansky to record another collection of covers, Tomorrow You‚Äôre Going \(Signature Sounds\), also produced by Larry Campbell. Consisting mostly of love songs, or love lost songs, it provided Shindell and Kaplansky an occasion to revel in their distinctive, two-part harmony with the backing of a top-notch band \(Byron Isaacs, Dennis McDermott, Bill Payne, and Campbell\) - all thanks to the participation of a committed community of fans who financed the project via the crowdfunding platform Kickstarter. The campaign more than doubled its funding goal in less than 48 hours. 

Shindell continues to tour nationally in the United States, with the occasional forays into Canada, the UK, and Europe. Although known primarily as songwriter, Shindell takes a more holistic view of his career. Producer, writer, singer, guitarist, interpreter: it all adds up to a life in music.

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?*¬†art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?*¬†is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit‚Äôs core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU‚Äôs Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: Developing Your Drawing Eye
description:
Schedule

Mondays, March 9 ‚Äì April 20, 2026 10:00 AM ‚Äì 1:00 PM Exceptions: No class March 23

Experience Level

Beginning

Drawing & Painting

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$270 ‚Äì Registration Cost $10 ‚Äì Materials Fee $280 ‚Äì Total Registration CostDeveloping Your Drawing Eye

Learn to draw without pressure or grades. Build foundational skills at your own pace through observational techniques. Perfect for beginners. Materials included.

What you‚Äôll do

It‚Äôs never too late to learn to draw ‚Äì especially when nobody‚Äôs grading you. Whether you are an abject beginner, haven‚Äôt picked up a pencil since high school, or you‚Äôre a creative who has always felt intimidated by observational drawing, this six-week class is offered with you in mind. We‚Äôll take the mystery ‚Äì and the pressure ‚Äì out of drawing from observation. You‚Äôll learn how to really see like an artist, practice simple techniques step by step, and build skills at your own pace. No talent required, and perfection is off the table. Studying observational drawing offers a foundational skill set that you will carry into every medium you might wish to explore. Discover the joy of drawing and build practical skills to expand your creative expression! All materials are provided.

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any class purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

title: Teach Truth Book Club: On Earth We're Briefly Gorgeous by Ocean Vuong
description:
Join us for a special event in collaboration with the Teach Truth Book Club. Organized by Hannah Henry, founder of Teach Truth California, each month the Teach Truth Book Club features an ethnic studies expert who will lead the discussion around a specific title and topic. Thank you for registering for this free event. Your RSVP helps us plan for your attendance. We look forward to welcoming you! ABOUT THE BOOK Named a Best Book of the Year by: GQ, Kirkus Reviews, Booklist, Library Journal, TIME, Esquire, The Washington Post, Apple, Good Housekeeping, The New Yorker, The New York Public Library, Elle.com, The Guardian, The A.V. Club, NPR, Lithub, Entertainment Weekly, Vogue.com, The San Francisco Chronicle, Mother Jones, Vanity Fair, The Wall Street Journal Magazine, and more! New York Times Readers Pick: 100 Best Books of the 21st Century ‚ÄúA lyrical work of self-discovery that‚Äôs shockingly intimate and insistently universal‚Ä¶Not so much briefly gorgeous as permanently stunning.‚Äù ‚Äî Ron Charles, The Washington Post On Earth We‚Äôre Briefly Gorgeous, the debut novel from the author of The Emperor of Gladness, is a letter from a son to a mother who cannot read. Written when the speaker, Little Dog, is in his late twenties, the letter unearths a family‚Äôs history that began before he was born ‚Äî a history whose epicenter is rooted in Vietnam ‚Äî and serves as a doorway into parts of his life his mother has never known, all of it leading to an unforgettable revelation. At once a witness to the fraught yet undeniable love between a single mother and her son, it is also a brutally honest exploration of race, class, and masculinity. Asking questions central to our American moment, immersed as we are in addiction, violence, and trauma, but undergirded by compassion and tenderness, On Earth We‚Äôre Briefly Gorgeous is as much about the power of telling one‚Äôs own story as it is about the obliterating silence of not being heard. With stunning urgency and grace, Ocean Vuong writes of people caught between disparate worlds, and asks how we heal and rescue one another without forsaking who we are. The question of how to survive, and how to make of it a kind of joy, powers the most important debut novel of many years. ABOUT THE AUTHOR Ocean Vuong is the author of the critically acclaimed poetry collections Night Sky with Exit Wounds, winner of the Whiting Award and the T. S. Eliot Prize, and Time Is a Mother, a New York Times bestseller. His writings have also been featured in The Atlantic, Harper‚Äôs, The Nation, The New Republic, The New Yorker, and The New York Times. Born in Saigon, Vietnam, he currently splits his time between western Massachusetts and New York City. On Earth We‚Äôre Briefly Gorgeous is his first novel.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

description:
Unwind, restore, and reconnect with your mind and body.¬†Designed for all levels, each session focuses on gentle yet purposeful poses, mindful breathing, and deep relaxation to help you release the stress of the day.

Whether you‚Äôre looking to improve flexibility, build strength, calm your nervous system, or simply create space for self-care, this class offers a supportive environment to nurture both body and mind. End your day feeling centered, refreshed, and rejuvenated.

What to Expect:

Gentle, mindful sequencing suitable for all levels

Focus on alignment, posture, and breath awareness

Deep stretches and calming poses to promote relaxation

Optional modifications to meet your individual needs

Bring a mat, water, and an open mind, and leave feeling balanced, relaxed, and ready for a restful evening.

About Carem

Carem Love is a wellness advocate, professional dancer, and certified yoga instructor with a Bachelor‚Äôs degree in Dance. She has extensive training in Bellydance, a deep passion for Latin dance, and is certified in Hatha, Vinyasa, and Children‚Äôs Yoga.

Yoga has profoundly supported her health, well-being, and dance career, inspiring her to help others experience the same body-mind benefits. In her classes, students strengthen their bodies, improve posture, mobility, balance and flexibility and learn to connect more deeply with themselves.

What to bring: ¬†mat, water, yoga blocks if you need them, and an open mind, and leave feeling balanced, relaxed, and ready for a restful evening.

Date & Time: Mondays @ 7PM

Address: 4140 Redwood Highway \#8 San Rafael, CA

Note: Arrive 10 minutes before. No floor marking shoe soles allowed.

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?*¬†art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?*¬†is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit‚Äôs core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU‚Äôs Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

description:
Discover your family story at our Family Search Center You will find our center in the Lakeport building in the room next to the nursery. Local volunteers can help jumpstart your family history journey. Our center is staffed on Tuesdays from 1pm - 4pm, reach us in person or by phone \(707\) 280-9545 during those hours. All services provided in centers are free. You‚Äôll enjoy: Personalized help Center guests can receive personal help from volunteers in one of more than 5,400 centers worldwide. Access to technology Centers offer complimentary access to computers, internet, and subscription family history websites. Available resources vary by location. Access to exclusive records Visitors to FamilySearch Centers get special access to images of historical records that are only available in centers. title: After School - Create Your Own Storybook World!
description:
Every Tuesday 3:30 PM ‚Äì 5:30 PM

Please see website: Exact dates are available on Enrichment.kids. Click the registration links below.

Experience Level

All Levels

Event Category: Kids

Age\(s\)

7-11

$100 ‚Äì Monthly Session Cost

Children will be inspired by a different artist each month and create 3D sculptural worlds from their own conceptualized 2D drawings.

What you‚Äôll do

In this imaginative, hands-on art class, young artists will explore the magical worlds of beloved artists & illustrators. Each month they will learn about a different artist: ¬†Phoebe Wahl \(January\), Antje Damm \(February\),¬†Karen Collins \(March\), Richard Scary \(April\), and Hayao Miyazaki \(May\)¬†. Inspired by their playful styles, students will¬†design and develop their very own characters‚Äîdeciding where these characters¬†live, work, play, eat, and sleep!¬†Students will be working independently as well as in groups to develop their visual storytelling muscles.¬† Children will create 3D sculptural worlds from their conceptualized 2D drawings. They will bring their stories to life using a mix of expressive art materials, including:

¬†watercolor, paint, pens,¬†and¬†collage

¬†recycled and found objects to build unique scenes

Together, we will learn:

How to use¬†watercolor techniques¬†to add color and mood

How¬†scale¬†helps characters and environments feel real

The¬†arc of a story‚Äîbeginning, middle, and end

How to build a world using¬†background, middle ground, and foreground

By the end of the class, each child will have created their own illustrated story scene full of imagination, personality, and creativity. A perfect class for kids who love drawing, storytelling, and building new worlds!

Pick-up & Drop-off

Drop off at 3:30 PM and pick up at 5:30 PM Drop-off and pick-up will happen outside Room 116 each week. For safety purposes, we ask that parents come inside to sign their child in and out after each session. You can view a map of our building here.

Pick-up Service

We also offer a free pick-up service for your kids if you are unable to drop them off after school. More more information, please contact Melissa Agocs at¬†melissa@sonomacommunitycenter.org.

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

Location

Room 116

title: Intermediate Salsa Class
description:
This class is designed for dancers who have a solid grasp of the basics and are eager to expand their repertoire with more complex and fluid movements.

Pre- requisite:

Salsa Class Beginners

Each week, we‚Äôll break down a new move, focusing on the technique and connection that will make you a more confident and stylish dancer. We‚Äôll go beyond the foundational steps to cover a wide range of essential intermediate patterns and styling, including:

Turns and Spins:

Master your inside and outside turns, double spins, and the elegant 360 and Hand Toss moves.

Intricate Patterns:

Learn to execute the 360, wrap, as well as various Cross Body Lead variations like the U-Turn and Spiral.

Footwork and Styling:

Enhance your rhythm and flair with advanced footwork like the Suzy Q, Front Tap, and Mambo Step. We‚Äôll also work on styling with a wrap and improving your posture and upper body movement.

This class is your chance to refine your technique, improve your lead-follow connection, and add a variety of fun and dynamic moves to your salsa vocabulary. Join us and elevate your dance!

Details:

No partner necessary ‚Äî rotations ensure everyone gets to dance.

Please wear¬†non-marking shoe soles¬†to protect the floor.

Arrive 10 minutes early to warm up and get settled.

Date & Time: Tuesdays @ 6:30PM ‚Äì 7:30PM

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Poetry Book Club: The Invention of the Darling by Li-Young Lee
description:
Each month, the Poetry Book Club meets online to discuss one must-read book of poems, whether a timeless classic or an award-winning contemporary. Led by Napa poet Kathleen Patterson, who has been an enthusiastic book club member since its beginning, meetings are open to all levels of poetry readers, both the curious and the committed. ABOUT THE BOOK A New Yorker and Publishers Weekly Best Book of 2024 Acclaimed poet Li-Young Lee offers a revelatory volume of ecstatic poems that search out divine voices in the silences of life, love, and death. ‚ÄúThe poet of rapture and tenderness‚Äù \(Major Jackson, American Poets\), Li-Young Lee speaks these poems with the intimacy and primacy of a whisper, as if from a lover to a beloved, or a believer to God. Each poem in The Invention of the Darling is a mysterious conjunction of spirit and matter, movement and stillness, the divine and the mundane, the sacred and the forbidden. They yearn for holistic union with The Beloved, every sentence another name for The Beloved, every poem another way to say ‚ÄúI love you.‚Äù Forged in awe of life and love, these poems emerge from the unlit depths of our earthly, material desires and our deepest fears of mortality. ABOUT THE AUTHOR Li‚ÄìYoung Lee is a poet and translator. He received the Ruth Lilly Poetry Prize for Lifetime Achievement, among other awards. Lee lives in Chicago.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

description:
Bachata with ALEX

Ready to take your bachata to the next level?

This intermediate bachata class is for dancers who have already mastered the basics and are ready for a new challenge. We‚Äôll build on your foundation with a focus on more intricate footwork, technique, and partner work.

Musicality to connect with the rhythm and emotion of the music

Feeling comfortable with your basic bachata steps and ready for more?

Our¬†intermediate bachata class¬†is designed for dancers who want to elevate their skills. We‚Äôll move beyond the fundamentals to focus on more complex¬†technique, footwork, and partner work.

This class will help you:

Refine your leading and following

Learn combinations and techniques

Develop your personal style and musicality

If you‚Äôre ready to add some fire to your dancing, this is the class for you!

Important Details

No partner necessary:¬†Come solo or bring a friend‚Äîeither way, you‚Äôll have plenty of opportunities to dance.

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?*¬†art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?*¬†is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit‚Äôs core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU‚Äôs Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

description:
Schedule

Wednesday, March 11 ‚Äì April 22, 2026 11:00 AM ‚Äì 1:00 PM

Location

Room 208

Experience Level

Intermediate

Drawing & Painting

Age(s)

18 and older

**$225** ‚Äì Registration CostAdvance your drawing skills with deep study of composition, value, and technique. Strengthen your creative process through focused practice.

About the Class

In this class, we will explore composition, value, and other aspects of drawing but on a deeper level. Beginning drawing classes have a lot of ground to cover so the concepts are skimmed over in order to give you exposure to as many as possible. Next-level drawing takes the time to do a deeper dive into some of the principles of drawing. When drawing we use limited tools which allow us to isolate both our strengths and weaknesses. Using this opportunity to really investigate our own process will serve to strengthen all aspects of our creative work. Drawing can be a challenge but when you see how it enhances the creative process, you will know it is worth it. This class is suitable for students who have a basic understanding of drawing and want to work on their skills. Please bring the following materials to class: 20‚Ä≥ x 26‚Ä≥ drawing board with clips, 18 ‚Äúx 24‚Äù Strathmore drawing pad (other brands are fine as long as the paper is drawing quality), soft willow charcoal, compressed charcoal (Char-kole brand black), white plastic eraser, notebook, Staedtler drawing pencils 2B and 6B, Pigma micron pens black (one fine-tip and one medium-tip).Membership has its benefits

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?*¬†art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?*¬†is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit‚Äôs core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU‚Äôs Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Barbies & Bags Workshop
location:
Bags! In addition to dolls, we‚Äôre expanding the exhibit to include bags‚Äîthink totes, clutches, cross bagsm fanny packs, coin purses, and backpacks. Just like the Trashion runway, the only rule is that your piece must be made from unconventional materials and/or upcycled/used textiles. $25 ‚Äì One Bag or Doll Entry $40 ‚Äì Two Bags or Dolls entryTransform plastic dolls and create upcycled bags from trash into unique art. Join our hands-on Trashion workshop for the Gallery 212 Exhibit and Auction.

About the Class

This hands-on workshop invites participants to rescue and reinvent plastic dolls \(Barbies, Kens, and dolls that are under 12 inches\) often destined for landfills, where they can take 20 to 500 years to decompose. As part of Trashion Season, join us for the beloved Gallery 212 Exhibit and Auction \(April 3 ‚Äì 25\) where discarded materials are transformed into small-scale works of art for a good cause. Together, we‚Äôll reclaim these forgotten figures and reimagine them as expressive, one-of-a-kind artworks for submission to the gallery exhibit and auction. New this year: Bags! In addition to dolls, we‚Äôre expanding the exhibit to include bags‚Äîthink totes, clutches, cross bagsm fanny packs, coin purses, and backpacks. Just like the Trashion runway, the only rule is that your piece must be made from unconventional materials and/or upcycled/used textiles. Participants will have access to access to sewing machines, hot glue guns, irons, hair dryers and other creative tools as well of a wide selection of trash and upcycled materials to bring their vision to life. BYOT \(Bring your own trash\) is also welcome and encouraged! The workshop registration is your application fee to the gallery exhibit! Come play, experiment, and collaborate while contributing to a dynamic gallery exhibit that raises funds for Sonoma Community Center programming through the auction. It‚Äôs a joy to see your art find a new home‚Äîand to be part of a creative community turning trash into treasure.

Thank you to Recology Sonoma-Marin for donating Barbies & Dolls for our gallery exhibit every year.

title: Napa Bookmine Book Club: Playground by Richard Powers
description:
Join us for a book club discussion! This year, 2026, Napa Bookmine Book Clubs' book picks will come straight from home, this year's Napa Bookmine BINGO Card! Each book will match a BINGO square. Hurrah! Play along with Napa Bookmine and read some new, fun books, and if you come to every meeting, you may get a BINGO in the meantime. ;\) This month, we'll be talking about Richard Powers's Playground. This is a free event, but we would appreciate your RSVP so we can plan for your attendance! Questions? Email us at events@napabookmine.com ABOUT THE BOOK New York Times Bestseller Finalist for the 2024 Kirkus Prize Longlisted for the 2024 Booker Prize As Seen on CBS Saturday Morning ‚Ä¢ A New York Times Book Review Editors‚Äô Choice ‚Ä¢ One of the Ten Best Books of the Year, according to the Washington Post and AARP ‚Ä¢ A Time Must-Read Book of the Year ‚Ä¢ An NPR "Books We Love" Pick ‚Ä¢ An Economist, New Yorker, and Kirkus Reviews Best Book of the Year "Prepare to be awed.‚Ä¶ \[A\]stonishing." ‚ÄîRon Charles, Washington Post The magisterial novel from the Pulitzer Prize‚Äìwinning and New York Times best-selling author of The Overstory and Bewilderment. Four lives are drawn together in a sweeping, panoramic novel from Richard Powers, showcasing the Pulitzer Prize‚Äìwinning author of The Overstory at the height of his skills. Twelve-year-old Evie Beaulieu sinks to the bottom of a swimming pool in Montreal strapped to one of the world‚Äôs first aqualungs. Ina Aroita grows up on naval bases across the Pacific with art as her only home. Two polar opposites at an elite Chicago high school bond over a three-thousand-year-old board game; Rafi Young will get lost in literature, while Todd Keane‚Äôs work will lead to a startling AI breakthrough. They meet on the history-scarred island of Makatea in French Polynesia, whose deposits of phosphorus once helped to feed the world. Now the tiny atoll has been chosen for humanity‚Äôs next adventure: a plan to send floating, autonomous cities out onto the open sea. But first, the island‚Äôs residents must vote to greenlight the project or turn the seasteaders away. Set in the world‚Äôs largest ocean, this awe-filled book explores that last wild place we have yet to colonize in a still-unfolding oceanic game, and interweaves beautiful writing, rich characterization, profound themes of technology and the environment, and a deep exploration of our shared humanity in a way only Richard Powers can. ABOUT THE AUTHOR Richard Powers is the author of fourteen novels, including The Overstory, Bewilderment, and Orfeo. He is the recipient of a MacArthur Fellowship, the Pulitzer Prize, and the National Book Award. He lives in the foothills of the Great Smoky Mountains.

title: Monthly Men's Circle - 3rd Thursday
location: The Unstruck Drum - Center for Shamanism
description:
This monthly gathering meets every third Thursday of each month. We have the intention of offering a safe space for all men who walk a path of seeking authenticity. Led by Collin Hoctor, this group brings community, shares wisdom, and brings healing to those who desire to walk a deeper, more meaningful life.

From Collin:

I am a psychotherapist and guide whose work weaves together spirituality, nature-based practices, psychedelic therapy, and recovery. My path has been shaped by a foundation in existential philosophy and psychology, medicine circles, and a lifelong study of contemplative and esoteric traditions. Out of my own longing for community and a commitment to the needs of the moment, I am passionate about creating spaces for men to gather in honesty, vulnerability, and authenticity ‚Äî places where we can face our struggles, share our truths, and remember the healing power of connection.

title: Samba no P√© - First Class
description:
Get ready to feel the rhythm and energy of Rio de Janeiro!¬†Samba no P√©¬†\(Samba in the Foot\) is the captivating solo style of samba danced in the streets and at Carnival, known for its rapid, intricate footwork and infectious hip movements.

You will learn

The Basic Step: You will master the signature quick-quick-slow rhythm that defines Samba no P√©.

Arm & Hip Styling: You will learn how to add the authentic flair, movement, and energy that makes Brazilian samba so captivating.

Technique & Posture: You will receive tips on proper body alignment to help you dance longer, faster, and more safely.

Rhythm & Musicality: You will learn how to connect your movement directly to the irresistible beat of the bateria \(the samba drum section\).

This class is perfect for anyone looking to connect with the vibrant spirit of Brazil, improve coordination, and get a fantastic workout‚Äîall while learning the foundational steps of this iconic dance. No partner or prior dance experience is required! Just bring your enthusiasm and comfortable shoes!

Date & Time: Thursdays @6:30PM ‚Äì 7:30PM

Address: 4140 Redwood Highway \#8 San Rafael, CA

Note: Arrive 10 minutes before. No floor marking shoe soles allowed.

title: Forr√≥ Dance with Eric and Abigail
description:
Get ready to connect, spin, and glide to the irresistible rhythms of¬†Forr√≥! Originating in the Northeast of Brazil, Forr√≥ is a captivating partner dance known for its close embrace, playful steps, and infectious, feel-good music. It is a social dance that will enrich your life, perfect for a night out or a casual gathering.

You Will Learn:

The Basic Step & Close Embrace: You will master the foundational quick-quick-slow rhythm and learn how to comfortably and confidently navigate the essential close-hold connection that defines Forr√≥.

Leading & Following Techniques: Discover the clear, subtle body cues required to effortlessly lead your partner through turns and variations, and how to follow with grace and responsiveness.

Traveling & Stationary Patterns: Learn fundamental steps like the ‚ÄòCaminhada‚Äô \(walking step\) and common stationary turns that will allow you to dance on any size floor.

Rhythm & Musicality: Connect your movement to the distinct musical styles of Forr√≥‚Äîfrom the mellow ‚ÄòXote‚Äô to the faster, more energetic ‚ÄòP√©-de-Serra.‚Äô

This class is perfect for anyone looking to learn a social partner dance, connect with Brazilian culture, and enjoy a vibrant, community atmosphere. No partner or prior dance experience is required! Just bring your enthusiasm and comfortable shoes!

Class Details

Note:¬†Arrive 10 minutes before. No floor marking shoe soles allowed.

title: Callie Watts
description:
Callie Watts is a singer/songwriter from Northern California who was raised on classical music, The Beatles and The Beach Boys before discovering Joni Mitchell, Elton John, Stevie Wonder, Paul Simon, Billy Joel, Carole King, and all the great writers of the ‚Äô60s and 70‚Äôs who have influenced her sound and writing style. After graduating high school, Callie began playing and performing solo, as well as in local and bay area bands of different genres. She‚Äôs played blues with Eric Lindell and the Reds, funky soul with Phatty, and jazz/swing with Savoy Swingers along with many other various projects. Callie has taken turns throughout her career as a keyboardist, guitarist, writer, and lead/backing vocalist, and she‚Äôs currently a member of the dynamic Sonoma County funk rock band Burrows and Dilbeck, having joined in 2010 as part of the former band Frobeck. Over time, she‚Äôs had the honor of opening for acts such as Bootsy Collins, Elvin Bishop, Huey Lewis and The News, War, Ozomatli, Bill Champlin, Booker T, and the B52s. Callie continues to perform frequently as an acoustic solo artist, focusing on developing a core audience and a buzz for her original material. Come hang out and listen at venues such as Aroma Roasters, Rincon Valley Tap Room and Bottle Shop, and Hopmonk Tavern.

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?*¬†art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?*¬†is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit‚Äôs core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU‚Äôs Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

title: Painting Flora and Fauna in Watercolor
description:
Schedule

Fridays, March. 20- April 24, 2026 10:00 AM ‚Äì 1:00 PM

Location

Room 208

Experience Level

All Levels

Drawing & Painting

Age(s)

18 and older

**$275** ‚Äì Registration Cost **$25** ‚Äì Materials Fee **$300** ‚Äì Total Registration CostIn this six-week course, participants will learn a unique approach to watercolor, intended to alleviate the frustration that many experience when learning this beautiful yet challenging medium.

About the Class

In this six-week course, participants will learn a unique approach to watercolor, intended to alleviate the frustration that many experience when learning this beautiful yet challenging medium. We will focus on strengthening one‚Äôs observational drawing skills, giving the artist a foundation off of which to build their paintings in a step-by-step layering process that trains the artist to see value and color. Our subject matter will be flora and fauna ‚Äì a sampling of plants and animals. These subjects are great for beginners and experienced artists alike; their organic shapes make them forgiving drawing subjects, but their beauty can be a muse for life.¬† Instructor Hannah Day is a passionate nature lover and watercolorist and will share her unique approach to rendering botanicals and animal portraits in watercolor. This class will work both from photographs and from life, practicing observational drawing in addition to watercolor technique. With six class sessions, participants will have the opportunity to develop their skills and build muscle memory with a medium that often feels like it has a mind of its own.¬† This class is open to artists of all skill levels. All materials are provided.

title: Emmylou Harris
location: Luther Burbank Center for the Arts
description:
Billboard¬†Century Award recipient, Harris‚Äô contribution as a singer and songwriter spans 40 years. She has recorded more than 25 albums and has lent her talents to countless fellow artists‚Äô recordings. In recognition of her remarkable career, Harris was inducted into the Country Music Hall of Fame in 2008 and earned a Grammy Lifetime Achievement award in 2018.

Harris is one of the most admired and influential women in music. She has recorded with such diverse artists as Linda Ronstadt, Daniel Lanois, Bob Dylan, Mark Knopfler, Neil Young, Gram Parsons, Willie Nelson, Dolly Parton, Roy Orbison, Ryan Adams, Beck, Elvis Costello, Johnny Cash, Lucinda Williams, Lyle Lovett and Rodney Crowell. Few artists have achieved such honesty or have revealed such maturity in their writing. Forty years into her career, Harris continues to share the hard-earned wisdom that‚Äîhopefully if not inevitably‚Äîcomes with getting older, though she‚Äôs never stopped looking ahead.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Safari West Presents! Save the Snakes
description:
Conservation Dinner Series: Michael G. Starkey of  Save the Snakes joins us in the elephant room after dinner to give a talk about California's snakes. The conservation dinner series is complimentary to all dinner guests. If you want to attend this presentation, please call our reservations team at \(707\) 566-3667 or \(800\) 616-2695 and they can book it for you. Dinner starts at 7:00 PM. Golden-State Snakes: An Introduction to Some of California's Most Spectacular Serpents This presentation teaches community members about the ecological importance of snakes, identification of Californian venomous vs non-venomous snake species, precautionary measures to avoid snakebites, and first aid and treatment in the event of a snakebite. You will also learn facts and dispel myths about snake species in your backyard! In this fun, interactive and family-friendly program, Save The Snakes Executive Director Michael Starkey will answer all your questions about snakes!    About the Speaker Michael G. Starkey is a conservation biologist, ecological consultant and public speaker working to educate and involve the public in wildlife conservation issues. Michael has a diverse background in the field of wildlife conservation and he has worked as an ecological consultant for environmental consulting firms and government agencies such as the U.S. Fish & Wildlife Service and the California Department of Fish & Wildlife. He has worked with a wide diversity of wildlife, including San Francisco garter snakes, giant garter snakes, California tiger salamanders, bats, ringtails and Yucat√°n black howler monkeys. Michael has developed and implemented community-based conservation initiatives that focused on the protection of wildlife populations in Belize, Ghana, and India. Michael is a Co-Founder of Save The Snakes and serves as Executive Director. He uses his knowledge of snake ecology, positive attitude to inspire, and enthusiasm for snake conservation to engage the public in protecting these beautiful animals. Michael has given presentations around the world to inform the public about the threats facing wildlife and to help nurture a society that respects and appreciates nature and wildlife.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Robbie Fulks
description:
Robbie Fulks is a singer, recording artist, instrumentalist, composer, and songwriter. His most recent release, 2017‚Äôs Upland Stories, earned year‚Äôs-best recognition from NPR and Rolling Stone among many others, as well as two Grammy¬Æ nominations, for folk album and American roots song \(‚ÄúAlabama At Night‚Äù\).

Fulks was born in York, Pennsylvania, and grew up in a half-dozen small towns in southeast Pennsylvania, the North Carolina Piedmont, and the Blue Ridge area of Virginia. He learned guitar from his dad, banjo from Earl Scruggs and John Hartford records, and fiddle \(long since laid down in disgrace\) on his own. He attended Columbia College in New York City in 1980 and dropped out in 1982 to focus on the Greenwich Village songwriter scene and other ill-advised pursuits.

In 1983 he moved to Chicago and joined Greg Cahill‚Äôs Special Consensus Bluegrass Band. He taught music at Old Town School of Folk Music from 1984 to 1996, and worked as a staff songwriter on Music Row in Nashville from 1993 to 1998. His early solo work -- Country Love Songs \(1996\) and South Mouth \(1997\) -- helped define the "alternative country" movement of the 1990s. His music from the last several years hews mainly to acoustic instrumentation; it returns him in part to his earlier bluegrass days, and extends the boundaries of that tradition with old-time rambles and sparely orchestrated reflections on love, the slings of time, and the troubles of common people.

Radio: multiple appearances on WSM‚Äôs ‚ÄúGrand Ole Opry‚Äù; PRI‚Äôs ‚ÄúWhadd‚Äôya Know‚Äù; NPR‚Äôs ‚ÄúFresh Air,‚Äù ‚ÄúMountain Stage,‚Äù and ‚ÄúWorld Cafe‚Äù; and the syndicated ‚ÄúAcoustic Cafe‚Äù and ‚ÄúLaura Ingraham Show.‚Äù TV: PBS‚Äôs Austin City Limits; NBC‚Äôs Today, Late Night with Conan O‚ÄôBrien, Later with Carson Daly, and 30 Rock. From 2004 to 2008 he hosted an hourlong performance/interview program for XM satellite radio, ‚ÄúRobbie‚Äôs Secret Country.‚Äù Artists who have covered his songs include Sam Bush, Kelly Hogan, Andrew Bird, Mollie O‚ÄôBrien, Rosie Flores, John Cowan, and Old 97s.

Robbie‚Äôs writing on music and life have appeared in GQ, Blender, the Chicago Reader, DaCapo Press‚Äôs Best Music Writing anthologies for 2001 and 2004,  Amplified: Fiction from Leading Alt-Country, Indie Rock, Blues and Folk Musicians, and A Guitar and A Pen: Stories by Country Music‚Äôs Greatest Songwriters. As an instrumentalist, he has accompanied the Irish fiddle master Liz Carroll, the distinguished jazz violinist Jenny Scheinman, and the New Orleans pianist Dr. John. As a producer his credits include Touch My Heart: A Tribute to Johnny Paycheck \(Sugar Hill, 2004\) and Big Thinkin‚Äô by Dallas Wayne \(Hightone, 2000\). Theatrical credits include ‚ÄúWoody Guthrie‚Äôs American Song‚Äù and Harry Chapin‚Äôs ‚ÄúCottonpatch Gospel.‚Äù  He served twice as judge for the Winfield National Flatpicking Guitar competition. He tours yearlong with various configurations.

Besides country and bluegrass music, Robbie is fiercely fond of Charles Mingus, P.G. Wodehouse, quantum mechanics, his wife Donna, comedy in almost all forms, cooking, swimming laps, the past, Arthur Schopenhauer, Universal horror movies, his grandson and even his sons, coastal towns in the off-season, and rye whiskey, though in nothing like that order.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Annadel Half Marathon, 10K, & 5K
description:
The Annadel Half Marathon is a non-profit fundraising event. Over the past 16 years, we have raised funds to make the park a more beautiful place for all to enjoy!¬†¬† The Half Marathon course is a hilly, and technical course designed for the experienced trail runner looking for a challenge. Enjoy gorgeous scenery with green meadows, wild flowers, and variety of beautiful trees. The race starts at the Spring Lake Oak Knolls picnic area and winds through Spring Lake Park before climbing into Annadel State Park. The Annadel Half Marathon is a tough course with over 1,500 feet of elevation gain over rocky and rooted terrain. The 5k course is an out and back route heading up a gravel fire road slightly into Annadel State park.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Bachata Beginners Saturday
description:
This class is perfect for bachata beginners that want to learn basic steps and skills, or those who want to refresh their foundational skills. We understand that learning something new can feel a little intimidating. That‚Äôs why our supportive and relaxed environment is specifically designed to make learning bachata basics an absolute blast!

Our friendly instructors will guide you through:

Basic directional steps:¬†You‚Äôll learn the fundamental movements that form the building blocks of all bachata dancing.

Proper frame for partner work:¬†Discover how to connect comfortably and effectively with a partner, setting you up for smooth and enjoyable dances.

Simple turn patterns:¬†We‚Äôll introduce you to easy-to-follow turn patterns that will have you dancing with a partner in no time.

We‚Äôve carefully organized our curriculum to ensure that each movement is easy to grasp and remember, building your confidence with every step. Our goal is to make learning fun. Join us to learn Bachata in Marin.

Important Details

No dance experience required:¬†Whether you‚Äôve never danced before or it‚Äôs been a while, you‚Äôre welcome here!

No partner necessary:¬†Come solo or bring a friend‚Äîeither way, you‚Äôll have plenty of opportunities to dance.

Please wear¬†non-marking shoe soles:¬†This helps us keep our dance floor in great condition.

Come join us and discover the joy of bachata! We can‚Äôt wait to see you on the dance floor.

Date & Time:

Thursdays @ 6:30PM ‚Äì 7:30PM Fridays @ 5:30PM ‚Äì 6:30PM Saturdays @ 9:00 AM ‚Äì 10:00 AM

Instructor: Lucie Ebnerova

title: Petaluma River High Tide Upstream Paddle
description:
When the tide is high, the Petaluma River opens into a quieter, greener world.

Join The Floathouse crew for a gentle, guided paddle upstream, timed to higher tides that allow access beyond the downtown channel and into a tranquil tidal slough. With extra water beneath us, we‚Äôre able to glide into calm, lush stretches of the river that are normally out of reach.

This unhurried paddle highlights the natural beauty of the Petaluma River‚Äôs brackish, tidal waterway. Watch for great egrets, blue herons, snowy egrets, turtles basking along the banks, and abundant plant life. The calm water and peaceful surroundings create a deeply grounding experience‚Äîmany guests say they feel their stress melt away within minutes.

Along the way, knowledgeable guides share stories of the river‚Äôs ecology and human history, offering insight into how this upper channel has shaped‚Äîand continues to shape‚ÄîPetaluma. It‚Äôs a rare opportunity to experience how close wild nature lives to the heart of downtown.

Beginner-friendly. Sit-on-top kayaks and all gear provided.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Outback Presents Justin Willman: One for the Ages Tour
location: Luther Burbank Center for the Arts
description:
Fresh off the release of Magic Lover, Netflix‚Äôs first-ever magic comedy special, Justin Willman is hitting the road with his all-new One for the Ages tour. Willman is best known as the star and creator of Netflix‚Äôs Magic for Humans and Magic Prank Show, where his signature mix of mind-blowing magic and relatable humor has made him a streaming favorite, a viral hit \(1 billion views and counting\), and a fan favorite for families, comedy lovers, and skeptics alike.

He‚Äôs appeared on The Tonight Show, The Today Show, The Kelly Clarkson Show, and Conan, and he was recently named ‚ÄúStage Magician of the Year‚Äù by the Magic Castle. He‚Äôs performed at the White House, packed theaters across the country, and managed to make grown adults openly weep over a card trick. But the live show? That‚Äôs where the real magic happens.

One for the Ages is Justin‚Äôs biggest tour to date, featuring brand-new material and more. It‚Äôs an interactive, laugh-filled, sleight-of-mind experience that‚Äôs smart, silly, and astonishing. And yes, it‚Äôs the kind of show you can bring your kids, your date, or your dad to. All ages. All generations. All-new.

This is one for the ages!

title: Spirit Sisters
location: Arlene Francis Center for Spirit, Art, and Politics
description:
SPIRIT SISTERS REIKI SHARE10AM - 12PM

Join us for a Reiki share to embrace

Embrace and share the power of energy healing, conveniently timed right before our monthly sister circle!

Join us as we exchange Reiki Energy Healing with one another, to support, heal and empower each other! This is a great opportunity to practice your Reiki or energy healing gifts in a safe communal space.

Release stress, restore balance and recharge your body, mind and spirit with our magical Reiki Circle. It consists of many healing hands on one person at a time.

Each share will start with a general introduction, then the circle will be grounded by one of our masters with a guided meditation, followed by treatments until each person has had a chance to receive healing.

This is a time and space for teachers, practitioners, those who are interested in sharing in connection and healing, as well as anyone who would like to learn more about Reiki.

Bring:

- A water bottle for yourself to replenish and hydrate

- Any healing tools such as tuning forks, crystals, etc. that you may want to use

- A $1 minimum cash, Venmo or PayPal donation

Join us afterwards for our monthly sister circle!

Spirit Sisters of Sonoma County is a spiritually based women's group for aligned women to be their true, authentic selves. Our events are to empower and connect with like-minded women in a safe and sacred space. Learn more about Spirit Sisters of Sonoma County at

spiritsistersinc.org .

\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_

\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_\_

SPIRIT SISTERS CIRCLE - 12:15PM - 3PM

For our March Sister Circle, we are honored to have community member Tara leading an Intuitive Art workshop!

In this workshop, you will learn how to use your intuition and expression in an artistic way. Through art, you'll learn how you can heal, play, transform and find answers within yourself!

No art experience necessary!

Bring:

- A Vegan Potluck Item

- A $1 minimum donation

Please:

‚Ä¢ We want anyone who is called to join us, and we'd rather you come late than not at all! We request that if you are running late, please enter through the front door of the building and enter the schoolhouse room quietly to prevent significant disruption to the group.

‚Ä¢ Due to our circles being a safe space for women to get vulnerable, this is an adult woman only event.

About the Sponsored Circle Host: Tara Dickinson

Tara grew up in an ashram \(intentional community\) with a spiritual teacher whose main message was kindness, feed everyone \(body, mind & soul\), and serve. Through these decades of inner work, silent meditation, and awareness, she can hold a space of stillness & understanding for others while we dive into what wants to be expressed.

With a background in fine arts and years of teaching a variety of art labs to kids & grownups, Tara enjoys sharing tools to help everyone feel comfortable in the creative process while learning new techniques.

Tara holds a Bachelor's in Fine Arts and works to combine her education and life experiences to create programs that encourage people to live their best lives by minimizing stress, opening to awareness, and making choices that are tailored to their needs and lifestyle.

More info can be learned at

Spirit Sisters of Sonoma County is a spiritually based women's group for aligned women to be their true, authentic selves. Our events are to empower and connect with like-minded women in a safe and sacred space. Learn more about Spirit Sisters of Sonoma County at

spiritsistersinc.org .

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: An Earth Day Journey of the Senses
description:
Guided by our Estate Garden Host, guests will embark on a sensory journey through Raymond Vineyards‚Äô gardens and vineyards, discovering the rhythms of the land, sustainable practices, and the living ecosystem that shapes every bottle we produce.

Along the way, sip wines crafted from the very vineyards beneath your feet, allowing each pour to reflect its place, season, and soil. The journey concludes with a thoughtfully curated cheese and charcuterie experience, designed to complement the wines and invite guests to linger, connect, and celebrate the beauty of the natural world.

This Earth Day, slow down, engage your senses, and honor the land that gives us so much.

title: A Taste Of Pine Mountain
description:

This curated experience brings together sweeping views, unreleased barrel tastings, and relaxed, thoughtful hospitality ‚Äî all led by winemaker¬†Doug Hackett¬†himself.

You‚Äôll begin with a welcome wine and bites as you take in the breathtaking scenery, followed by an intimate barrel tasting of unreleased wines from¬†Spicy Vines and Pine Mountain Vineyards.¬†Afterward, we‚Äôll settle in for a laid-back BBQ lunch, generous pours, and easy conversation ‚Äî the kind that only happens when you slow down and savor where you are.

This isn‚Äôt just another tasting. It‚Äôs a rare opportunity to experience Pine Mountain in a way few ever do.

title: Tea and Tarot: Element of Earth Business & Prosperity
location: Magick Oak - Metaphysical Center & Enchanted Goods
description:
Tea & Tarot • Grounded Growth Edition

Earth energy governs stability, resources, value, embodiment, and what we are here to build in the material world. In this Earth-themed Tea & Tarot gathering, we focus on business, livelihood, prosperity, and sustainable growth — not through hustle or pressure, but through alignment, structure, and embodied worth.

This experience is designed for entrepreneurs, creatives, and anyone in a season of building. Tarot is used as a reflective tool to explore your relationship with money, work, and long-term vision, helping you clarify what wants to take root and what needs stronger foundations.

What We'll Explore

    •    Your current relationship with money, work, and value

    •    Where energy is supporting growth — and where it may be leaking

    •    Structures, boundaries, or systems that want refinement

    •    How to grow prosperity in ways that feel ethical, sustainable, and embodied

What's Included

    •    A grounding opening to anchor intention and presence

    •    Individual tarot pulls focused on business and material flow

    •    Practical reflection prompts you can apply immediately

    •    Tea service to support nervous system regulation and clarity

This is not about quick fixes or financial prediction. It is about conscious stewardship of your energy, time, and resources — and building something that can last.

Who This Is For

    •    Entrepreneurs, small business owners, and creatives

    •    Those navigating career transitions or expansion

    •    Anyone redefining their relationship with money and worth

    •    Tarot beginners and experienced readers alike

Earth teaches us that prosperity grows through care, consistency, and honest self-assessment. This gathering offers a supportive container to listen to what your work and resources are asking of you — and how to respond with clarity and confidence.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: What About Age? Art Exhibit
description:
*What About Age?*¬†art exhibit has arrived in Marin County! Originally displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows, this exhibit explores ageism through contemporary art, featuring works by both local youth and senior artists.

*What About Age?*¬†is an art exhibit and educational initiative designed to challenge stereotypes about aging, address ageism and social isolation, and promote intergenerational dialogue through the lens of art.

In partnership with Youth in Arts, the exhibit features artworks by local youth and senior artists, showcasing how age intersects with creativity, identity, and experience. Under the guidance of Youth in Arts, these emerging and established artists work side by side to create collaborative pieces, fostering meaningful connections between generations and reflecting the exhibit‚Äôs core message: art is ageless.

The exhibit also includes artwork panels by New York-based writer and illustrator Aubrey Hirsch, first displayed at NYU‚Äôs Kimmel Windows and originally organized by Stacey Gordon, NYU‚Äôs Program Director of Next Phase Adult Caregiving and Retirement at Work Life.

The new exhibition will be on view at the Marin County Civic Center galleries from January 26 to May 6, 2026. Works will be displayed on the first and third floor exhibits, Monday to Friday from 9 a.m. to 6 p.m.

The *What About Age?* art exhibit is presented by Marin Cultural Association in partnership with Marin Community Foundation and Youth in Arts. Beyond the art exhibit, the *What About Age?* initiative offers programming, led by Vivalon, designed to challenge ageism and provide resources for Marin County's growing aging population.

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Developing Your Drawing Eye
description:
Schedule

Mondays, March 9 ‚Äì April 20, 2026 10:00 AM ‚Äì 1:00 PM Exceptions: No class March 23

Experience Level

Beginning

Drawing & Painting

Age\(s\)

18 and older

$270 ‚Äì Registration Cost $10 ‚Äì Materials Fee $280 ‚Äì Total Registration CostDeveloping Your Drawing Eye

Learn to draw without pressure or grades. Build foundational skills at your own pace through observational techniques. Perfect for beginners. Materials included.

What you‚Äôll do

It‚Äôs never too late to learn to draw ‚Äì especially when nobody‚Äôs grading you. Whether you are an abject beginner, haven‚Äôt picked up a pencil since high school, or you‚Äôre a creative who has always felt intimidated by observational drawing, this six-week class is offered with you in mind. We‚Äôll take the mystery ‚Äì and the pressure ‚Äì out of drawing from observation. You‚Äôll learn how to really see like an artist, practice simple techniques step by step, and build skills at your own pace. No talent required, and perfection is off the table. Studying observational drawing offers a foundational skill set that you will carry into every medium you might wish to explore. Discover the joy of drawing and build practical skills to expand your creative expression! All materials are provided.

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any class purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

Room 116

title: Brainstormer Trivia with Rick Tosh
description:
So, Trivia-Mongers,¬†you think you're smart? Here's your chance to prove it. Join Quizmaster, Rick Tosh for "Brainstormer Trivia". Six rounds of compelling trivia that boggles the mind and stirs the soul! An entertaining evening of fun, and ephemera in a friendly team trivia competition. Pit your wits against friends and other intelligent life. Show off your astounding knowledge of pop culture, movies, music, sports, science, literature, famous faces, and more. Order delicious food and drinks while you play! Win HopMonk Gift Cards, fabulous prizes and bragging rights. Prizes for 1st, 2nd, and Average Team Score...It's FREE to play! Enjoy food and drink specials are available for purchase during the quiz! Free to Play!!

Source: North Bay Bohemian

title: Yoga with Carem - Restore, Rejuvenate, Reconnect
description:
Unwind, restore, and reconnect with your mind and body.¬†Designed for all levels, each session focuses on gentle yet purposeful poses, mindful breathing, and deep relaxation to help you release the stress of the day.

Whether you‚Äôre looking to improve flexibility, build strength, calm your nervous system, or simply create space for self-care, this class offers a supportive environment to nurture both body and mind. End your day feeling centered, refreshed, and rejuvenated.

What to Expect:

Gentle, mindful sequencing suitable for all levels

Focus on alignment, posture, and breath awareness

Deep stretches and calming poses to promote relaxation

Optional modifications to meet your individual needs

Bring a mat, water, and an open mind, and leave feeling balanced, relaxed, and ready for a restful evening.

About Carem

Carem Love is a wellness advocate, professional dancer, and certified yoga instructor with a Bachelor‚Äôs degree in Dance. She has extensive training in Bellydance, a deep passion for Latin dance, and is certified in Hatha, Vinyasa, and Children‚Äôs Yoga.

Yoga has profoundly supported her health, well-being, and dance career, inspiring her to help others experience the same body-mind benefits. In her classes, students strengthen their bodies, improve posture, mobility, balance and flexibility and learn to connect more deeply with themselves.

What to bring: ¬†mat, water, yoga blocks if you need them, and an open mind, and leave feeling balanced, relaxed, and ready for a restful evening.

Date & Time: Mondays @ 7PM

Address: 4140 Redwood Highway \#8 San Rafael, CA

Note: Arrive 10 minutes before. No floor marking shoe soles allowed.

description:
Discover your family story at our Family Search Center You will find our center in the Lakeport building in the room next to the nursery. Local volunteers can help jumpstart your family history journey. Our center is staffed on Tuesdays from 1pm - 4pm, reach us in person or by phone \(707\) 280-9545 during those hours. All services provided in centers are free. You‚Äôll enjoy: Personalized help Center guests can receive personal help from volunteers in one of more than 5,400 centers worldwide. Access to technology Centers offer complimentary access to computers, internet, and subscription family history websites. Available resources vary by location. Access to exclusive records Visitors to FamilySearch Centers get special access to images of historical records that are only available in centers. title: After School - Create Your Own Storybook World!
description:
Every Tuesday 3:30 PM ‚Äì 5:30 PM

Please see website: Exact dates are available on Enrichment.kids. Click the registration links below.

Experience Level

All Levels

Event Category: Kids

Age\(s\)

7-11

$100 ‚Äì Monthly Session Cost

Children will be inspired by a different artist each month and create 3D sculptural worlds from their own conceptualized 2D drawings.

What you‚Äôll do

In this imaginative, hands-on art class, young artists will explore the magical worlds of beloved artists & illustrators. Each month they will learn about a different artist: ¬†Phoebe Wahl \(January\), Antje Damm \(February\),¬†Karen Collins \(March\), Richard Scary \(April\), and Hayao Miyazaki \(May\)¬†. Inspired by their playful styles, students will¬†design and develop their very own characters‚Äîdeciding where these characters¬†live, work, play, eat, and sleep!¬†Students will be working independently as well as in groups to develop their visual storytelling muscles.¬† Children will create 3D sculptural worlds from their conceptualized 2D drawings. They will bring their stories to life using a mix of expressive art materials, including:

¬†watercolor, paint, pens,¬†and¬†collage

¬†recycled and found objects to build unique scenes

Together, we will learn:

How to use¬†watercolor techniques¬†to add color and mood

How¬†scale¬†helps characters and environments feel real

The¬†arc of a story‚Äîbeginning, middle, and end

How to build a world using¬†background, middle ground, and foreground

By the end of the class, each child will have created their own illustrated story scene full of imagination, personality, and creativity. A perfect class for kids who love drawing, storytelling, and building new worlds!

Pick-up & Drop-off

Drop off at 3:30 PM and pick up at 5:30 PM Drop-off and pick-up will happen outside Room 116 each week. For safety purposes, we ask that parents come inside to sign their child in and out after each session. You can view a map of our building here.

Pick-up Service

We also offer a free pick-up service for your kids if you are unable to drop them off after school. More more information, please contact Melissa Agocs at¬†melissa@sonomacommunitycenter.org.

Membership has its benefits

All Silver Memberships and above receive 10% off the registration cost for any purchase over $40. Materials fees are not discounted.

Become a member today and find community, connection, and creativity.

Room 116

title: Intermediate Salsa Class
description:
This class is designed for dancers who have a solid grasp of the basics and are eager to expand their repertoire with more complex and fluid movements.

Pre- requisite:

Salsa Class Beginners

Each week, we‚Äôll break down a new move, focusing on the technique and connection that will make you a more confident and stylish dancer. We‚Äôll go beyond the foundational steps to cover a wide range of essential intermediate patterns and styling, including:

Turns and Spins:

Master your inside and outside turns, double spins, and the elegant 360 and Hand Toss moves.

Intricate Patterns:

Learn to execute the 360, wrap, as well as various Cross Body Lead variations like the U-Turn and Spiral.

Footwork and Styling:

Enhance your rhythm and flair with advanced footwork like the Suzy Q, Front Tap, and Mambo Step. We‚Äôll also work on styling with a wrap and improving your posture and upper body movement.

This class is your chance to refine your technique, improve your lead-follow connection, and add a variety of fun and dynamic moves to your salsa vocabulary. Join us and elevate your dance!

Details:

No partner necessary ‚Äî rotations ensure everyone gets to dance.

Please wear¬†non-marking shoe soles¬†to protect the floor.

Arrive 10 minutes early to warm up and get settled.
